title: Why do atoms have empty space? - Quora

response.answer_text: view that an atom mostly consist of empty space stems from the old times when Bohr's atomic model (as a miniature planetary system in which electrons surround the nucleus) was the best picture of what an atom is like.But there are no electron particles moving around an atom. One cannot view the electrons as little balls moving inside a molecule and somehow avoiding falling into a nucleus. Such a configuration would be unstable. The nuclei would attract little charged balls until they fall into them.But it is very well understood why atoms are stable - the ground state is a delocalized stationary state of the electrons in an atom, a state living indefinitely (unless the nucleus decays). In terms of quantum field theory, the space is filled by the electron field. The resulting electron density can be calculated by quantum mechanics. Empty space is sort of a tricky concept, especially on the atomic scale. We say that “most of the atom is empty space” to emphasize that the atomic nucleus is incredibly tiny compared to the atom as a whole, and that the electrons are so ethereal as to almost be non-existent. If that’s true, why don’t the electrons simply collapse down closer to the nucleus, shrinking the atom a million-fold? Part of it has to do with quantum mechanics; electrons can only exist in certain allowed orbits, because they’re both particles and waves. Electrons must orbit the nucleus in such a way that their path represents a whole number of wavelengths, which means there will be regions where electrons cannot orbit. But here’s the thing: Given electrons’ wavelike characteristics, it’s impossible to pinpoint an electron to one specific location. The electrons of an atom are really “smeared out” over a range of possibilities centered on the nucleus. So we could claim that most of the atom is empty space, but it’s probably more accurate to say that most of the atom’s volume is occupied by the wave functions of electrons, over which electrons are spread out.
